title: Liverpool legends including Gerrard and Carragher will face Real Madrid in front of a sell-out crowd at Anfield
text:
Get Liverpool FC   
Liverpool legends Steven Gerrard and Jamie Carrager make an emotional return to Anfield on Saturday as a sell-out crowd will see them play for a legends team against Real Madrid. 
Over 53,000 fans will show their loyal support for the LFC Foundation as some of the biggest names in the game will be on show for the match that gets underway at 3pm. 
According to the Liverpool Echo, Gerrard and Carragher will line up alongside other Liverpool legends such as Michael Owen, John Aldridge, Daniel Agger, Luis Garcia, Gary McAllister with Ian Rush operating as a player/manaer. Liverpool's Steven Gerrard applauds fans as he walks on the pitch with his family after his final game at Anfield (Photo: Reuters) Read More Steven Gerrard takes on 3 Liverpool legends in brilliant shooting challenge 
Real Madrid legends will include the likes of Roberto Carlos, Emilio Butragueño and Luis Figo. 
The game is the return fixture from one played at Madrid’s Bernabeu stadium as the Corazon Classic in June 2015 when the hosts ran out 4-2 winners, helped by some controversial refereeing decisions. 
That attracted a 70,000 plus crowd too and the appetite for the fixture is clearly huge. 
Andrea Cooper, head of the LFC Foundation, the official charity of Liverpool FC, said so far everything was going according to plan. Steven Gerrard celebrates after scoring the second goal for Steven Gerrard All-Stars from the penalty spot (Photo: Reuters) 
Ms Cooper said: “Everybody’s coming and we’re really excited about the game. It’s the UK debut if you like for the official Liverpool Legends team. The Bernabeu was the first game a couple of years ago and then we played Manchester United in Stockholm, so this is the first at Anfield as well. 
“All the signs are really positive. We’re going to have a sold-out stadium, like the All-stars game a couple of years back, but of course with an even bigger stadium now. 
”It’s one of those projects where everybody wins really. The players absolutely love it, they really want to play, to wear the shirt again, to play in front of the new Main Stand for the first time, to see each other again, to have a reunion and share the old stories, and of course just to play a game, maybe score a goal. Rush will manage the Liverpool legends (Photo: Mark Kolbe/Liverpool FC via Getty) 
“The fans love it, they’ve all got their favourite players they want to see again so it's a chance for them to see their heroes and of course we’ll be raising a significant amount of funding for for the Foundation and our new strategy which is focused very heavily on improving the life chances and opportunities for children and young people.” 
The final figure raised from that All-Star game in 2015 - which saw the return of Luis Suarez and Fernando Torres to Anfield - was more than £1m but there are no firm targets for Saturday’s occasion, which will also be followed by the normal shirt auctions in the weeks which follow it. Robbie Fowler and Michael Owen are set to be re-united once again (Photo: Getty) 
The money raised will be allocated at the end of year and split between the programmes of the Foundation itself and three charity partners. This year they include Alder Hey hospital, a University of Liverpool project to help improve the number of children from the Anfield area entering higher education and a Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine project to use the club to help encourage people to access health support. 
Steve McManaman is set to repeat his feat of of playing for both sides, as he did in the Bernabeu, having represented both during his career, while Michael Owen may well do the same. 
Also turning out for Liverpool include Patrik Berger, Dietmar Hamann, Jerzy Dudek, Stephane Henchoz, John Arne Riise, Jason McAteer, Vladimir Smicer, David Thompson, Bjorn Tore Kvarme, Sander Westerveld, Salif Diao and Phil Babb, poll loading Did Steven Gerrard retire too early? 1000+ VOTES SO FAR
